results.content:
TLDR; I would recommend the course, but you should already have a good foundation in the following skills: Python, Django, HTML, CSS, Bootstrap.  Also, know that you may need to repeat some parts of the videos multiple times to understand the what is being said. 

Michele is pretty thorough in his coverage of the subject matter and the course follows a clear and logical progression.  I definitely learned a lot.  I would argue that you need a bit more in the way of prerequisites for the course though.  At a minimum, it would help to have some knowledge of bootstrap and a pretty good grasp of Python as well as be pretty familiar with Django (also html and CSS).  If you do not have that background, I would start there as Michele assumes you know that material already.  There were quite a few times where I could not always understand what he was saying and either had to repeat the section or sometimes just move on as I still could not understand it even after listening to it a few times.  I did not find that closed caption was very helpful as it is not always that accurate.  His command of English is very, very good, but his accent makes some of the pronunciations tough to understand.  I found this somewhat of a hindrance in learning parts of the material as the subject matter is obviously very technical.  If I did it over, I would have been better versed in bootstrap before taking it, which I am not (next course for me!).

results.content:
This is a perfect Django rest framework course. compared to other Django courses that I bought from top instructors, this explains things in a very clear and understandable way. he hardly skips any concept. He talks about everything, different view methods in creating your CRUD, serializers are explained PERFECTLY. everything is just wonderful. He also talks about authentication in a detailed way. I haven't finished the course but will update my rating as I progress.

[update] I finished this course, went on and built a big project, and I have to say this course worked wonders for me. you would be able to build almost anything. 
My only criticism which could be a suggestion for the next course, if he considers doing one more:
1) a more detailed course about authentication (signup or sign in) the one here is good, but he could do a lot better and could maybe do something more custom for the future

2) deployment with environments for testing and production. This is the point that I am stuck at with building my own project and I am constantly looking for resources.

In summary: this course is a MUST GET. it is the best Django rest api content I have seen on udemy, and trust me I have a bunch of courses on them.

results.content:
I took this course to learn how to use authentication and token authentication in Django-REST-framework. 
Learn how to connect the frontend and the backend components (during development and on production). 
Learn how to design the backend project (what logic should be in the views, serializers, models, etc)

This course answered my question and now I feel more comfortable building my own app from scratch.

The thing that was missing in my opinion was some feature overview before some of the big features. Explaining a bit at a high level what changes need to be done and how everything will be connected can be helpful before starting coding (and we can try first coding on our own from requirements).
That is it, overall I recommend this course.

Very clear and complete explanations on how to use the core features of DRF, including details on how those features were implemented, and the reasoning behind.

The Vue part was also great, but a little bit fast-paced. I still need to figure out what would be the best way to make Vue and Django Templates play together - I want to mix both templates - but this is an awesome way to get familiar with the framework.

I'm waiting anxiously for the author to update the course for Vue3.

Thank you for preparing this great course, Michele Saba! Hope to see more courses in english from you!

results.content:
Currently working through the course. Will update the review as I finish.

Nearing the end of the Django sections - 

The instructor is very knowledgeable and the course is structured very well (at least for Django). It starts out by teaching you the basics of Django by showing you some of the lower level capabilities. The course then expands in later sections by using higher abstraction level features that are more powerful. Personally I feel like this teaches me a better understanding of some of the inner workings of Django by easing you into the features. 

The instructor is also well spoken and tries to explain why Django does things a certain way whether it be convention or any other reason. 

Small constructive criticism - Maybe in the future in a different course include a few more interesting technologies like Docker, Jenkins, etc.



Edit - Course finished. The Vue.js sections were great and instructional as the DJango ones were.

I wish he did not use copy and paste all over the lesson because I end up just trying to find where he copied code from rather than focusing on what it's doing. It's still a very good course and if you're more familiar with Django than I am perhaps you may have an easier time following.

Update 1:
After receiving a response to my initial review I stand by my criticism. I think this course is good. The content covered is more than I would expect with a 13 hour course. I have a coworker that took a 25 hour course from someone else on Vue that still said some of the things covered by Michele weren't in the longer course. There is a lot of content and it is good content. 

However I am still of the opinion that when teaching people a new skill you should first do everything the long way. I am sure it is just habit but the way Michele jumps around the code to copy and paste as little as one word from a different file is needlessly jarring. My opinion is the course would be better organized and easier to follow if he was a little more willing to type things. 

I also believe that the end of the course project should be structured more like the previous competency assessments. Cover the material and then let us practice it with a project. The capstone project that is the end of the course and the largest section of the course at 4.5 hours introduces new techniques, packages, and tools that weren't included at all in the actual lectures.

I also don't think that it is at all appropriate to reply to every critical review and assume it is the users fault and that they need to complete a more basic course in order to understand this one. In my case I can comprehend the material just fine. I simply believe the presentation could have been more fluid and easier to follow if done a little differently. 

I did raise my review from 3.5 to 4 stars because Udemy describes that as "Good, what I expected". This course is good and I do and have recommended it, despite the fact that I find the instructors behavior regarding review comments to be insulting.

response.content:

I now fully understand the scope of your criticism and I thank you for that. I really appreciated the long format of this new review and the level of detail provided. I will keep your precious advise in mind for any future course I might create.

results.content:
This course is great. I like how the lecturer goes into a bit more detail from developing DRF from the basics and then moving to more high level classes and also diving a little into the class libraries and explaining what you're importing. Bonus points for the VS code hints at the start to make dev more efficient. 

I would request that every now and then lectures get added to keep up to date with the best methods for combining Django and Vue. One example would be Axios which seems to provide a good library for asynchronous tasks. I understand the pace of development of the two frameworks is rapid but even just a high level intro into recommended libraries would be great (and how to implement them together which is often the hardest part) where we can take it form there.

results.content:
Awesome course so far. I just finished Section 3, and I can confidently say I know how to create a simple API using Django and the Django Rest Framework on my own. Can't wait to get through the rest of this!

Also, this course is listed as being about 13 hours. But in my case, I would say I am a begginer/intermediate-level python/all around programmer. That being the case my method for taking this course has been: 1) Watch 2)Pause Video 3)Take Notes 4)Recreate Code. And this, while paying attention to detail, and taking my time to try to really understand what is happening, has significantly increased the material digestion time frame. I think I take about 1 hour for each 10 -15 min video LOL.


What I'm saying is, this course is PACKED with material. I'm sure you could zoom through this in a couple days, as I normally would with any other course, but if you take your time I think you'll get a lot out of it.

Definitely 10000% recommend.

results.content: As an experienced django dev who hasn't used django rest framework much, this is great! I'm following along and adding an API to one of my apps, and seeing the rationale behind code I've observed in the API where I work. The instructor explains very clearly, and is more pleasant to watch and follow along than it would be to read docs. One should still read the docs eventually, but this is a great way to have fun making something that works quickly, and then getting all the details later. and honestly if you just want a simple API and don't want to read the docs, after this course you probably won't really need to. He covers all the main points, including security and authentication. Highy recomended!

response.content:
Hello William.

Thanks for your feedback.

However please remember that this is an intermediate / advanced level course, therefore basic knowledge of Django is assumed. You need to know Python, what classes are, and how the MTV architecture works. Otherwise you need to just follow a beginner - level course first.

Also, this course is divided into sections with a progressive approach to content explanation.

Therefore you will need to understand every single lesson before moving to the next one, if you wish to actually understand.

This stuff is used by some of the biggest and most profitable companies in the world: it is therefore normal that you actually need some time to process all the information given.

It is not as easy as watching a tv series on NetFlix, sorry about that.

Hopefully you will improve as the course goes on, as for most of the people that have enrolled, and that's why the average rating is above 4.5 stars.

I remember you also that you can ask for a complete refund withing 30 days from the purchase date.

Happy Coding!
Michele

results.content:
this course is gold. really this is THE course I needed to quickly get started to django.
as django has a very extensive documentation and most instructors usually show their own way of doing things it's hard to get on track.
This is where Michele comes. This course teaches you how to build an API from scratch. From a flask-like approach using only request and JSONRenderer to slowly showing you where DRF trully shines (serializers, models, APIViews, generics, mixins, routers).
I already knew vuejs but that like button :css switch was pretty neat!! rly learning day by day
the course is super fast paced and indeed all those copy, pasting and scrolling makes it sometimes dizzy especially when you'r 1.25x 1.5x.
overall one of the top courses i've seen so far

I strongly recommend this course.

response.content:
I do not agree at all with this review.

99% of the students who have enrolled this course have found it to be an excellent course, and that's why the average score is higher than 4.5 stars.

The description of the course is also very much explicit: knowledge of Python and Django is required, as this is an intermediate / advanced level course.

Therefore, the teaching approach used assumes that you know how to add this advanced knowledge to something that you already have.

I suggest you ask for a complete refund, you have a right to it up to 30 days from purchase date, and then maybe enroll to a much more basic level course.

Bye,

99% of the students who have enrolled this course have found it to be an excellent course, and that's why the average score is higher than 4.5 stars.

The description of the course is also very much explicit: knowledge of Python and Django is required, as this is an intermediate / advanced level course.

Therefore, the teaching approach used assumes that you know how to add this advanced knowledge to something that you already have.

I suggest you ask for a complete refund, you have a right to it up to 30 days from purchase date, and then maybe enroll to a much more basic level course.

Michele

results.content:
Michele is an enthusiastic and clearly knowledgeable teacher.
As someone who has been a developer for a few years, I wanted to see what the hype around Django Rest Framework was. 
Michele's approach of starting at the basics, setting a foundation of understanding for the student before gradually moving forward with the various different levels was very good. It's always nice to see course authors invest some time in teaching their students how to test the code that they have written too.

The main reason why the course unfortunately falls short of 5 stars is mainly because a lot of the Vue section felt rushed. I didn't personally learn anything new in it that I didn't already know - which is fine - but if I was someone who was new to Vue, I would probably benefit more from using Vue-resource or Axios and probably even implementing Vuex in the project. JWT authentication would also elevate the course to 5 stars. Alongside that, the quality of some of the code on the front-end was slightly lacklustre and I felt like the teacher could have spent more time building smaller, dumber components and set an example for the student to follow - which the back-end certainly was. I do also get that the front-end was more of a bonus to the course though and rushed to inspire students to start building.

Those are my two cents. Thanks for the course!

results.content:
Section 1 and 2 have been well planned, progress clearly and at a good pace. I'm already familiar with most of the content so far, but have picked up some nice approaches such as configuring Visual Studio Code for Django runserver instead of using a separate terminal.

Sections 3, 4 and 5 progress similarly well, particularly the way the lower level options are explored first before building up to the more magical methods like ViewSets and Routers. The course also picks up some speed as it progresses through these sections so never feels laboured. Having built production code with DRF, I was again familiar with most of the things covered, but not in as methodical a way as presented. It's therefore been great to relieve the "imposter syndrome" that comes from having built something even while not necessarily understanding all of the working parts.

The rest of the course moved into Vue.js which is completely unfamiliar to me and I watched with the following question "Is this going to be appropriate for my needs or are there any blockers that mean I'll have to look for another solution?". I'm happy to say the detail of the course allowed me to answer yes and no respectively to those questions and now it's time to move all that I've learned from the course into real world code.

Thanks Michele for an enthusiastically energetic and detailed course!
